docs.title: isx: a pure-python API to read Inscopix data
docs.text: isx is a lightweight pure-python API for reading Inscopix data files.

docs.title: Nomenclature and Description
docs.text:
This repository is distinct from the Python API for IDPS, which is also called isx.

This repository The IDPS API Freely available to the public (under a NC-BY license, see License for details) Requires access to IDPS Only Python support Python and MATLAB support Pure python implementation. Should work on any system that can run Python Implemented in C++ with Python (or MATLAB) bindings No user support Support via standard Inscopix channels for Inscopix customers

Drop in replacement for the IDPS API

The goal of this repository is to act as a drop-in replacement for the IDPS Python API (for reading ISXD files). Therefore, code here is structured to mirror classes and functions in the IDPS Python API.

isx or py_isx?

This repository is called py_isx, but defines a package called isx. Therefore, you would import this as follows:

import isx

The reason for this is so that it can be used as a back-end for code that was written for the IDPS Python API, without requiring any change in user code.

docs.title: User Support
docs.text:
No user support

This repository is provided as-is, with no ongoing support from Inscopix.

docs.title: Data Support
docs.text:
Currently, isx supports only a subset of Inscopix data types.

File type Support ISXD CellSet ✅ ISXD Movie ✅ GPIO data ❌ ISXD Events ❌ ISXD VesselSet ❌

docs.title: General Information
docs.text: Contributions to py_isx are welcome, but no guarantee is made that your contributions will be merged, or responded to.

docs.title: Reporting bugs
docs.text: Please report bugs using our issue tracker on GitHub. Unsolicited bug reports cannot be guaranteed a response.

docs.title: Install latest version of code
docs.text:
If you plan to use this in your own project, use your favorite package manager to install this in your project.

pippoetry 
# you are strongly encouraged to install in a virtual envrionment
pip install git+https://github.com/inscopix/py_isx.git@main

poetry add git+ssh://git@github.com/inscopix/py_isx.git

docs.title: For Developers
docs.text:
Developers only

The instructions below are only if you intend to develop py_isx. If you merely want to use this API to read data, you do not have to do this.

docs.title: Get the code
docs.text: git clone git@github.com:inscopix/py_isx.git

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Make sure you have poetry and make installed. Verify that both are installed:

make --version
# GNU Make 3.81

poetry --version
# Poetry (version 1.7.1)

docs.title: Install locally
docs.text:
You can then install the API locally by navigating to the directory you downloaded the code in, and running:

poetry lock
poetry install --all-extras

Poetry installs using a "editable" install, so changes you make will be reflected in the code executed.

docs.title: How to read ISXD Cellset files
docs.text:
We first import py_isx using:

import isx

docs.title: Read a CellSet
docs.text:
CellSets can be easily opened in Python using the isx.CellSet.read method. 

cell_set = isx.CellSet.read('cellset.isxd')
Now that you have a CellSet object, you can use it to access the data in the file.

docs.title: Get the number of cells in the CellSet
docs.text:
num_cells = cell_set.num_cells
With this information, you can pull the data from specific cells, or iterate over all of the cells in the file.

docs.title: Get the trace from a cell
docs.text: ```python

docs.title: Read name of a cell in a CellSet
docs.text:
Assumptions

This section assumes you:

  1. have the API installed,
  2. have imported it using import isx
  3. have a ISXD CellSet accessible on your local file system at cellset.isxd

Once a cell set is opened using:

cell_set = isx.CellSet.read("cellset.isxd")
we can read the name of any cell using:

cell_name = cell_set.get_cell_name(0)

docs.title: Read status of a cell in a CellSet
docs.text:
Assumptions

This section assumes you:

  1. have the API installed,
  2. have imported it using import isx
  3. have a ISXD CellSet accessible on your local file system at cellset.isxd

Once a cell set is opened using:

cell_set = isx.CellSet.read("cellset.isxd")
we can read the status of any cell using:

cell_status = cell_set.get_cell_status(0)

docs.title: Read a frame from a movie
docs.text:
Assumptions

This section assumes you:

  1. have the API installed,
  2. have imported it using import isx
  3. have a ISXD movie accessible on your local file system at movie.isxd

First, open the movie for reading using:

movie = isx.Movie.read("movie.isxd")

Then, read the frame of interest by index:

frame = movie.get_frame_data(0) # reads the first frame

frame now contains a numpy array with the frame data for the first frame.

Indexing

Note that python indexes by 0, so the first frame is at index 0, and the the second frame is at index 1, and so on.

docs.title: Read movie timing information
docs.text:
Assumptions

This section assumes you:

  1. have the API installed,
  2. have imported it using import isx
  3. have a ISXD movie accessible on your local file system at movie.isxd

Once a movie is opening using:

movie = isx.Movie.read("movie.isxd")

timing information can be accessed using:

movie.timing

The number of frames can be accessed using:

movie.timing.num_samples

and the time period can be accessed using:

movie.timing.period.secs_float

docs.title: API Reference: Classes
docs.text:
How to use this reference

This page contains information about every Class and function in this package. This is meant as a detailed reference for this code. If you're looking to do something specific, the How To section may be more useful.

docs.title: isx.Movie
docs.text:
IDPS Equivalent

This class is designed to be equivalent of the isx.Movieclass in the IDPS Python API

The Movie class allows you to create objects that represent ISXD movies. Every Movie object is bound to a ISXD movie file that exists on disk.

Attributes:

Name Type Description file_path str

path to ISXD file

footer dict

A dictioanry containing data in the JSON footer of ISXD Movies

timing Timing

a isx.Timing object containing timing information for this movie

spacing Timing

a isx.Spacing object containing spacing information for this movie

docs.title: read classmethod
docs.text:
read(file_path: str)

Open an existing movie from a file for reading.

This is a light weight operation that simply reads the meta-data from the movie, and does not read any frame data.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default file_path str

The path of the file to read.

required

Returns:

Type Description

A isx.Movie object. The movie that was read. Meta-data is immediately available. Frames must be read using isx.Movie.get_frame.

docs.title: get_frame_data
docs.text:
get_frame_data(index: int)

Read the contents of a single frame in a movie

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default index

The numeric index of the frame.

required

Returns:

Type Description

The retrieved frame data.

docs.title: isx.CellSet
docs.text:
The CellSet class allows you to read ISXD CellSets.

How to use the CellSet class

To see how to use this class to read data from ISXD Cellsets, click here. This reference page describes each member of this class and what each function does.

docs.title: read classmethod
docs.text:
read(file_path: str)

method to maintain compatibility with IDPS API. This doesn't actually do anything very interesting other than set the timing and num_cells property

docs.title: get_cell_trace_data
docs.text:
get_cell_trace_data(cell_id: int) -> np.array

return trace for a single cell

docs.title: get_cell_image_data
docs.text:
get_cell_image_data(cell_id: int) -> np.array

This method reads the spatial footprint of a single cell and returns that as a Numpy array.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default cell_id int

index of cell of interest

required

Returns:

Type Description array

A MxN Numpy array containing frame data where M and N are the pixel dimensions

docs.title: get_cell_name
docs.text:
get_cell_name(cell_id: int) -> str

return name of cell

docs.title: get_cell_status
docs.text:
get_cell_status(cell_id: int) -> str

return status of cell

docs.title: isx.Duration
docs.text:
IDPS Equivalent

This class is designed to be equivalent of the isx.Durationclass in the IDPS Python API`. Not all features of the IDPS Python API are mirrored here.

Attributes:

Name Type Description secs_float float

A period of time, expressed in seconds.

docs.title: isx.Timing
docs.text:
IDPS Equivalent

This class is designed to be equivalent of the isx.Timingclass in the IDPS Python API`. Not all features of the IDPS Python API are mirrored here.

Attributes:

Name Type Description period Duration

An instance of isx.Duration with information about the period

num_samples int

The number of time samples in this object.

docs.title: isx.Spacing
docs.text:
IDPS Equivalent

This class is designed to be equivalent of the isx.Spacingclass in the IDPS Python API`. Not all features of the IDPS Python API are mirrored here.

Attributes:

Name Type Description num_pixels tuple[int, int]

A 2-tuple containing the dimensions of the frame.

docs.title: isxd_type
docs.text:
isxd_type(file_path: str) -> str

infer ISXD file type

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default file_path str

path to ISXD file

required Source code in isx/__init__.py 
@beartype
def isxd_type(file_path: str) -> str:
    """infer ISXD file type

    Parameters:
        file_path: path to ISXD file

    """

    metadata = _extract_footer(file_path)

    isx_datatype_mapping = {
        0: "miniscope_movie",
        1: "cell_set",
        2: "isxd_behavioral_movie",  # not currently supported on IDEAS
        3: "gpio_data",
        4: "miniscope_image",
        5: "neural_events",
        6: "isxd_metrics",  # not currently supported on IDEAS
        7: "imu_data",
        8: "vessel_set",
    }
    return isx_datatype_mapping[metadata["type"]]

docs.title: _footer_length
docs.text:
_footer_length(isxd_file: str) -> int

find the length of the footer in bytes

Source code in isx/__init__.py 
@beartype
def _footer_length(isxd_file: str) -> int:
    """find the length of the footer in bytes"""

    with open(isxd_file, mode="rb") as file:
        file.seek(-8, os.SEEK_END)
        data = file.read()
    footer_length = struct.unpack("ii", data)[0]

    return footer_length

docs.title: _extract_footer
docs.text:
_extract_footer(isxd_file: str) -> dict

extract movie footer from ISXD file

Source code in isx/__init__.py 
@beartype
def _extract_footer(isxd_file: str) -> dict:
    """extract movie footer from ISXD file"""

    footer_length = _footer_length(isxd_file)

    with open(isxd_file, mode="rb") as file:
        file.seek(-8 - footer_length - 1, os.SEEK_END)
        data = file.read(footer_length)

    footer = data.decode("utf-8")
    return json.loads(footer)

docs.title: _get_isxd_times
docs.text:
_get_isxd_times(input_filename)

Get the timestamps of every sample of an isxd file from its metadata.

The timestamps are generated by getting the average sampling period of the isxd file.

:param input_filename str: path to the input file (.isxd) :return: The timestamps of every sample in the isxd file

Source code in isx/__init__.py 
def _get_isxd_times(input_filename):
    """Get the timestamps of every sample of an isxd file from its metadata.

    The timestamps are generated by getting the average sampling period
    of the isxd file.

    :param input_filename str: path to the input file (.isxd)
    :return: The timestamps of every sample in the isxd file
    """

    metadata = _extract_footer(input_filename)
    period = (
        metadata["timingInfo"]["period"]["num"]
        / metadata["timingInfo"]["period"]["den"]
    )
    num_times = metadata["timingInfo"]["numTimes"]
    times = np.linspace(
        0,
        (num_times - 1) * period,
        num_times,
    )
    return times
